Name: Cathedral Church of St. Mary
Notes: Foundations laid April 25, 1220. Consecrated 1225, 1258 and when completed in 1266.

Name: Salisbury Cathedral School
Notes: Initially residential, now a private school.

Name: Malmesbury House
Notes: Original known as Copt Hall demolished in 1399, still residential.

Name: The Theological College
Place: North Walk, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EG
Notes: Now called Sarum College, an ecumenical study centre.

Name: The Close Wall, Rosemary Lane
Place: Rosemary Lane, North Walk, The Close, Salisbury, also Exeter St. Salisbury
Notes: The ancient wall surrounding the Cathedral close on north, east and south sides. Remnants of Old Sarum Cathedral visible.

Name: The Matron's College
Notes: Accommodation for clergy widows. Established by Bishop Seth Ward and probably designed by Christopher Wren, still functions with original intent.

Name: North Gate
Notes: Two-storey building over and around north entrance to the Cathedral Close.

Name: Mompesson House
Place: Choristers' Green, The Close Salisbury. SP1 2EG
Notes: Town house built for Sir Thomas Mompesson, 17/18th century MP, now a historical exhibit.

Name: Screen, Walls, Piers, Gates and Overthrow of Mompesson House
Place: Choristers' Green, The Close Salisbury. SP1 2EG
Notes: Frontage of house, low wall, iron gate and railings,18th century iron lamps.

Name: Wren Hall
Place: Choristers' Green, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EL
Date: 14/15th century wing of Braybrook House rebuilt in 1714
Notes: Originally a cathedral choristers' school, now used as a cathedral education centre.

Name: Braybrooke House
Notes: Initially residential, now a resource centre.

Name: Hemingsby House
Place: Choristers' Green, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EL
Notes: Former canonry, has appearance of two houses.

Name: The King's House
Place: West Walk, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EG
Notes: Originally the residence of the Abbot of Sherborne, now a museum.

Name: 68 West Walk
Notes: Residential to the present day

Name: Retaining Wall, Screen Railing, Piers and Gates of No. 68 West Walk
Place: 68 West Walk, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EN
Notes: Iron decorative screen with gate and low wall.

Name: The Walton Canonry
Place: No. 96 West Walk, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EN
Notes: A private residence, named from earlier resident, Canon Walton, son of the angler, still residential.

Name: Leaden Hall
Place: West Walk, The Close, Salisbury. SP1 2EP
Notes: Original site of canonical house of Elias of Dereham, now part of a private school.

Name: South Gate or Harnham Gate and Gatehouse
Notes: Archway, gate and gatehouse. Southern gate into Cathedral Close.

Name: Bishop's Gate
Notes: The eastern gateway into Cathedral Close

Name: St Annes Gate
Notes: Originally a residence and gateway, now only partly residential but still a gateway.

Name: Church of St. Lawrence
Date: Early C13 chancel but consecration recorded for 1326.
Notes: Parish Church of the village of Stratford sub Castle

Name: Church of St Martin
Place: St Martin's Church St., Salisbury. SP1 2HY
Notes: Originally a Saxon church, several restorations.

Name: Church of St Thomas and St Edmund
Notes: Parish church of New Sarum.

Name: John Halle's Hall
Notes: Originally residential, now entrance to Odeon cinema.

Name: 91 Crane Street
Notes:
Residential.
Previously called 'Le Crane' in 1455

Name: The King's Arms
Notes: Probably residential initially, later and now, an inn.

Name: The Old George Inn
Notes: This old inn has a number of literary and historical connections, now, with ground floor removed, entrance to shopping mall. No longer an inn.

Name: Church House
Notes: Originally donated by the Audley family as a workhouse, now diocesan administrative offices.

Name: Joiners' Hall
Notes: Initially a guild meeting hall, now residential

Name: Mill House and Old Mill
Notes: Mill house, restored early 19th century, now with hotel attached.

Name: School of Arts Annexe
Notes: Originally part of Salisbury School of Art, now offices.

Name: The Poultry Cross
Notes: Originally to mark the site of a market. Still used as a market site twice weekly.

Name: Trinity Street Almshouses
Notes: 2 storied medieval hospital and accommodation rebuilt in 1702, now accommodation for elderly people.

Name: Crane Bridge
Notes: 4 span bridge over River Avon.

Name: Harnham Bridge or Ayleswade Bridge
Notes: The oldest bridge in Salisbury. Built by Bishop Bingham over the River Avon

Name: Remains of Old Sarum Castle and Cathedral
Notes: Originally an important town and citadel, now a historical site.
